Correction Operator

Correction operator for group ownership model

  • (Definition.) Define the correction operator DDD as
    D=diag((I−W)−1)−1D = \text{diag}((I-W)^{-1})^{-1}D=diag((I−W)−1)−1
  • This operator will be used to elaborate upon the correction to the self-loop problem proposed by Baldone et al. (1998)
  • As the inverse of a diagonal matrix is simply the inverse of each of its entries, DDD itself is a diagonal matrix with
    {Dij=0 if i≠jDii=1(I−W)ii−1\begin{cases} D_{ij} = 0 \text{ if}\ i \neq j \\ D_{ii} = \frac{1}{(I-W)^{-1}_{ii}} \end{cases}{Dij​=0 if i=jDii​=(I−W)ii−1​1​​
  • In "Group Ownership Refinements", it was proposed to simply remove the self-loop term: W^ij=Wij+(∑j=1nW^ikWkj)−W^iiWij\hat{W}_{ij}=W_{ij}+(\sum_{j=1}^{n}\hat{W}_{ik}W_{kj})-\hat{W}_{ii}W_{ij}W^ij​=Wij​+(∑j=1n​W^ik​Wkj​)−W^ii​Wij​. In matrix form, this could be written W^=(I−diag(W^))W+W^W\hat{W}=(I-\text{diag}(\hat{W}))W+\hat{W}WW^=(I−diag(W^))W+W^W, or:
    (I−diag(W^))−1W^=W(I−W)−1(I-\text{diag}(\hat{W}))^{-1}\hat{W}=W(I-W)^{-1}(I−diag(W^))−1W^=W(I−W)−1
  • It was proposed by Baldone et al. that W^\hat{W}W^ has solution equal to
    W^=diag(V)−1(V−I)\hat{W} = \text{diag}(V)^{-1}(V-I)W^=diag(V)−1(V−I)
    where V=(I−W)−1V = (I-W)^{-1}V=(I−W)−1. We can thus also write D=diag(V)−1D = \text{diag}(V)^{-1}D=diag(V)−1 according to the above definition.
  • (Lemma.) DDD can also be written I−diag(W^)I - \text{diag}(\hat{W})I−diag(W^).
  • (Proof.) Take the diagonal of both sides of the above equation, and use the identity diag(A+B)=diag(A)+diag(B)\text{diag}(A+B)=\text{diag}(A)+\text{diag}(B)diag(A+B)=diag(A)+diag(B):
    diag(W^)=diag(diag(V)−1(V−I))=diag(V)−1diag(V−I)=diag(V)−1(diag(V)−I)=I−diag(V)−1=I−D\begin{aligned} \text{diag}(\hat{W})&=\text{diag}(\text{diag}(V)^{-1}(V-I)) \\ &= \text{diag}(V)^{-1}\text{diag}(V-I) \\ &= \text{diag}(V)^{-1}(\text{diag}(V)-I) \\ &= I - \text{diag}(V)^{-1} \\ &= I - D \end{aligned}diag(W^)​=diag(diag(V)−1(V−I))=diag(V)−1diag(V−I)=diag(V)−1(diag(V)−I)=I−diag(V)−1=I−D​
    and thus
    D=I−diag(W^).D = I - \text{diag}(\hat{W}).D=I−diag(W^).
  • Without this refinement, we defined W^=W(I−W)−1\hat{W}=W(I-W)^{-1}W^=W(I−W)−1.
  • Thus, from
    (I−diag(W^))−1W^=W(I−W)−1(I-\text{diag}(\hat{W}))^{-1}\hat{W}=W(I-W)^{-1}(I−diag(W^))−1W^=W(I−W)−1
  • We have I−diag(W^)=DI - \text{diag}(\hat{W}) = DI−diag(W^)=D and Wnew^=DWold^\hat{W_{new}} = D\hat{W_{old}}Wnew​^​=DWold​^​.
  • Interpretation. The correction proposed by Baldone et al. is simply equal to multiplying the ownership matrix by the correction operator DDD.
  • (Theorem.) As the integrated value νint\nu^{int}νint is defined W^v\hat{W}vW^v, we simply have νcorrectedint=Dνint\nu^{int}_{corrected} = D\nu^{int}νcorrectedint​=Dνint as the corrected value. We also write the corrected network value as vcorrectednet=Dvnetv^{net}_{corrected}=Dv^{net}vcorrectednet​=Dvnet, and furthermore D(νint+v)=νcorrectedint+DvD(\nu^{int}+v)=\nu^{int}_{corrected}+DvD(νint+v)=νcorrectedint​+Dv due to an above theorem.
  • (Theorem.) The corrected network value is vcorrectednet=Dvnetv^{net}_{corrected} = Dv^{net}vcorrectednet​=Dvnet.
  • Thus, the correction operator allows us to multiply all of the network value vinetv^{net}_ivinet​, the integrated portfolio value νiint\nu^{int}_iνiint​, and the underlying value viv_ivi​ by DDD.
    • As DDD is a diagonal matrix, these values are multiplied by Dii=1−W^iiD_{ii}=1-\hat{W}_{ii}Dii​=1−W^ii​. This makes the self-loop correcting aspect quite intuitive.
